Expectation1: Ensure compliance with tax laws and regulations.
Situation1: A notice has just arrived from the tax authority indicating a discrepancy that requires an immediate response.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I sat at my desk, the tax notice trembling in my hand. As the company’s accountant, I was expected to respond immediately, ensuring every document was in order and every law followed to the letter. My phone buzzed with reminders from my manager—this was urgent, and any delay could mean penalties. But tonight was the community event I’d promised to attend, a rare gathering with friends and family. When I arrived, the aroma of food filled the hall, but my heart sank. None of the dishes had kosher certification, and there was no way to substitute or bring my own meal without drawing attention. My colleagues and friends expected me to join in, to share the meal and the moment. I felt the weight of my roles pressing in—one demanding my immediate attention to legal detail, the other calling me to uphold my faith and traditions. My mind raced, torn between the urgent call of my profession and the quiet, persistent voice of my beliefs. I stood at the edge of the room, caught between two worlds, unsure which expectation I would have to disappoint.
